channel.title: Building a Computer
channel.description:
Hi, well let me say one thing before I get started. I know 99% of my posts are in Moparscape, but I would much rather it be 99% of my posts over here. There's nothing but a bunch of leechers and people that know the very basics of java, and have no purpose if they're not willing to learn.
ANYWAYS, I'm building a computer right now, and I wanted your opinion on the setup:
Case: Thermaltake VI Mx VH9000BWS; PSU: ThermalTake 850w; Mother Board: Giga-Byte GA-EP35-DS3R; CPU: Intel Quad-Core Q9550(2.83 Clock speed, 1333 MHz FSB, 12MB L2 Cache) RAM: OCZ DDR2 PC2-8500 Fatal1ty 4GB Dual Channel x 2(8 gigs total) Hard Drives: 1: 320GB Western Digital 2: 1TB Western Digital 3: 1TB Western Digital 4: 1TB Western Digital
CD/DVD Drive: Plextor PX-850SA OS: Windows XP Professional SP2C 64-bit Graphics Card: EVGA GeForce GTX 280 Video Card - 1GB GDDR3
Those are the parts I'm hoping to buy, but if you have any better choices, I would gladly take them into consideration. The parts with a ';' after it are the parts that I currently have.

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Ok, thanks. I don’t really like the RAID systems all that much, so I think I’ll just have 4 independent drives. I think I’m also going to setup a triboot system, With Vista Ultimate 64-bit, XP Pro 32-bit, and Fedora 10.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:15, topic:268115”]Ok, I’ll check it out, Thanks ^_^, Also what do you suggest for the Hard drives? This is what I would like to start with:

1: 320 GB
2: 1 TB
3: 1 TB
4: 1 TB

1 + 2 + 3: Into a RAID5(2.3 TB)
4: Independent Drive(“D:”, 1 TB)

Would that work well? According to T4_, I shouldn’t have more than 3 Drives in a RAID5, and They shouldn’t be more than 320 GB each.[/quote]
To answer your question about stability, it is true. Larger drives have more platters = more change of damage. Also, I don’t know what the hell you have, but to be 1TB if a lifetime of data (as long as it isn’t HD videos). As for the RAID 5 array, 3 drives is minimal; just use 3 drives.

The formula for RAID 5 diskspace is: 0.77(totalDiskSpace); so 3 320GB HDDs = 740GB that acts as one drive. May I remind you that RAID 5 can support up to 9 drives (10+ is RAID 10); but if you go over 4, you’ll need a 600WAT PSU. Also RAID 5 is striping AND mirroring. If one disk fails, pop another in and all information will transfer to it. Also, transfer speeds on RAID 5 are higher than in a standard configuration; the OS has (in this case) 2 disks to write data to at once, adding a multitasking element to the disks.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

zyle1992:

Well, I’m planning on running a few different private servers on it. Like a WOW server, MU server, RS server. Hosting a website, maybe get a FTP server on it. Not really sure I want to do with it all, but I’m hoping that this will last me a long time.

That computer should do well hosting those servers. I know that motherboard supports 1000mb/s LAN but out of pure curiosity how fast it your broadband connection?

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

So you mean a 7200 rpm, 1 TB hard drive, w/SATA interface has a higher chance of data loss than, lets say a 500 GB Drive?

UPDATE: Ok, this is my new setup, with the appropriate changes:

Case: Thermaltake VI Mx VH9000BWS;
PSU: ThermalTake 850w;
Mother Board: Giga-Byte GA-EP35-DS3R;
CPU: Intel Quad-Core Q9550(2.83 Clock speed, 1333 MHz FSB, 12MB L2 Cache)
RAM: OCZ DDR2 PC2-8500 Fatal1ty 4GB Dual Channel x 2(8 gigs total)
Hard Drives:
1: 320GB Western Digital
2: 1TB Western Digital
3: 1TB Western Digital
4: 1TB Western Digital

CD/DVD Drive: Plextor PX-850SA
OS: Windows XP Professional SP2C 64-bit//Maybe dual boot withe Fedora 10…
Graphics Card: GeForce GTX 285 1GB 512-bit GDDR3

I’m also having trouble finding a PCI wireless adapter that will be compatible the 64-bit XP… Any help finding one would be greatly appreciated.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

zyle1992:

Ya, Of course I want it to last. I actually was debating whether or not I should have 4 seperate drives, or put them into a RAID array. I definitely want one separate physical drive. PUttin the other 3 into a RAID5 doesn’t sound too bad though. Why wouldn’t I want more than 320 Gb Hdds?

Larger hard drives = slower + more chance of data loss.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Niall:

Don’t go with vista, go with XP 64bit.

Niall is correct.

[quote=“xEnt, post:7, topic:268115”]zyle1992: that setup is fine, if you have the money or need that much storage.

T4_:

PSU: Overkill, 500WATS is fine.

Show me a 500w that will run 4 7200rpm hard drives, that quad core cpu and the GTX280, and ill remember you never said that.[/quote]

I have a 420WAT PSU in my gaming machine which is identical and/or requires slightly more power than his. I have a SAS SCSI RAID 0 which are 2 15K RPM drives, a 8800GTX, (had) a QuadCore of that same model (upgraded mb to 1366), DDR3 RAM @ 1.8GHz.

Also to zyle1992, do not get more than 3 drives at RAID 5; and defiantly don’t buy drives > 320GB. You want this thing to be fast and last, right?

Read full topic

That’s a lot of stuff to power. Infact, when I calculated the approximate wattage needed, it came out to about 670w.

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Ya, I’m going to be gaming a lot. I was actually hoping to have a dual boot system. Like when I turn on the computer, a screen pops up(looks like a dos window), and it gives you a choice of the OS’s you can run. Like on my cousins computer, he has Ubunutu, Windows XP, and Windows Media center. I was hoping to do something like that, but specifically just for Vista, and a linux distro, like Fedora 10, and maybe XP. That downside is that Vista uses alot more resources. So Which would you recommened? Strictly Vista, Strictly XP, Strictly Fedora 10, or a combination of the 3? I mean, I am going to have 3 TB’s of space,(probably going to update the 320 GB to 1 TB after I get it going…)

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

I would have chosen DDR3 RAM, but the mobo I got only uses DDR2, and The other mobo I was thinking of buying, the EP35C-DS3R only had 2 DDR3 slots, and 4 DDR2 slots. As for the OS, I was actually debating yesterday whether I should choose a linux distro, like Fedora, or Ubuntu, or using the 64-bit Vista. I’ll have to check out the CD/DVD drive though. Thanks for the suggetions ^_^.

Read full topic

item.title: Building a Computer
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:1, topic:268115”]Case: Thermaltake VI Mx VH9000BWS;
PSU: ThermalTake 850w;
Mother Board: Giga-Byte GA-EP35-DS3R;
CPU: Intel Quad-Core Q9550(2.83 Clock speed, 1333 MHz FSB, 12MB L2 Cache)
RAM: OCZ DDR2 PC2-8500 Fatal1ty 4GB Dual Channel x 2(8 gigs total)
Hard Drives:
1: 320GB Western Digital
2: 1TB Western Digital
3: 1TB Western Digital
4: 1TB Western Digital

CD/DVD Drive: Samsung SH-S223Q
OS: Windows Vista Ultimate 64-bit SP1
Graphics Card: EVGA GeForce GTX 280 Video Card - 1GB GDDR3[/quote]

Case: Fine
PSU: Overkill, 500WATS is fine.
Mother Board: Good choice, although I’ve had some funny things happen with these motherboards. (Nothing bad, just make sure you flash the BIOS before using); Make sure it has RAID support.

CPU: Good, but if you have more money purchase an i7 + LGA 1366 Socket motherboard.
RAM: OCZ is a very good manufacture, I’d suggest DDR3, though.
Hard Drives: No, No no… purchase 3 320GB SATA/300 hard drives and RAID 5.

CD/DVD Drive: Buy a Plextor.
OS: NO!, install Fedora Core 10 x86_64 and VM Windows XP.
Graphics Card: EVGA is a good company, nice pick.

Overall, good picks; but you messed up a little (or sometimes a lot) on some.

Read full topic
